STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
September 15, 2025
Courtney Atkins
CLARE COUNTY DHHS
725 RICHARD DR,
HARRISON, MI, 48625-9289
RE: License#: CP180201067
Dear Courtney Atkins:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on 09/15/2025. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective
action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact WOC area manager Shay Mavis at (269) 243-2725.
Sincerely,
Mark Hunter, Licensing Consultant
enclosure
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except for
the following:
CPA Rule 400.12405 Change of placement
• (5) If an agency is no longer providing services
to the child in a foster home, then both the
following must be documented before a change
in placement:
• (a) A summary of the services provided
during care up to the time of the change
in placement and the needs that remain
to be met.
One of the two foster care youth records reviewed who were discharged did not
include the information required for compliance with this rule. This information is
typically included in the DHHS 69 documentation, but this report could not be
located in this example.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
There was no technical assistance requested or required.
V. CONSULTATION
There was no consultation requested or required.

VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 2 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows:
A CAP was required for the interim evaluation completed 12/1/2024. Areas
identified in noncompliance as a part of that evaluation were Rules 327-6-a, 327-
6-c, and 327-7. None of these areas were identified in noncompliance as a part of
this renewal evaluation. The CAP continues to be Active/Monitoring at this time.
A CAP was also required for special investigation #2025SIC0000286. Licensing
Rule 324-2-d was identified to be in noncompliance as a determination of that
special investigation. This area was not identified in noncompliance as a part of
this renewal evaluation. The CAP continues to be Active/Monitoring at this time.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator Annual Assessment included a review of the CAP
requirements associated with the interim annual review evaluation. The
assessment identified providing additional information, training, and supervision in
achieving and maintaining compliance with the approved corrective action plan.
None of the areas identified in the corrective action plan were identified in
noncompliance as a part of this renewal evaluation.
Financial Overview
N/A
Staff Interviews
Child Welfare Staff participated in entrance and exit conferences. Staff interviews
did not indicate any areas of concern.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency maintains sufficient office space, equipment and supplies to ensure
delivery of foster care, licensing and independent living services. All files were
stored securely and there is a cross shredder for CHRI.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
Safety Alert #1: One home required an additional smoke detector, and water safety
equipment to be available for a water hazard.

Resolution: The required smoke detector was provided and installed, and the water
safety equipment was placed where it was accessible if needed. Picture
documentation was provided for compliance and DCWL approved 6/12/2025.
Safety Alert #2: One home needed an additional smoke detector.
Resolution: The smoke detector was provided and installed. Picture documentation
confirmed compliance, and DCWL approved 6/17/2025.
Safety Alert #3: The home needed an additional smoke detector.
Resolution: The additional smoke detector was provided and installed. Picture
documentation confirmed compliance and DCWL approved 6/23/2025.
Safety Alert #4: One home needed door alarms on the door exiting to a water
hazard area.
Resolution: The door alarms were installed and picture documentation for
compliance was provided. Compliance approved by DCWL 7/02/2025.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
09/15/2025
_____________________________________
Mark Hunter Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
September 15, 2025
Shannon (Shay) Mavis Date
WOC Area Manager
